Fury, Furie, n. [ME. fury(e, furie, OF. furie.]

1. Violent rage, frenzy. Doug. ii. vi. 38.

The fury cachit our myndis hait as fyre Ib. iii. iv. 12; etc.

Fury of goddis cummys from hellis grund Bell. Livy I. 168/26.

The maieste of consullis mycht nocht abandoun the instant furie of pepill Knox II. 57.

In quhilk poynt God brydillit thair furye Rolland Seven S. 10523.

In greit furie I did it and wodnes Dalr. II. 20/34.

This quhen thay hard thay culd nocht be satisfiet … all war in a furieattrib. Doug. v. i. 13.

Eneas … knew alsso quhat thyngis mycht be controvyt By women in fury rage that strangly luffyt

b. In law: Violent insanity. Skene Reg. Maj. ii. 33.

Inquisition salbe taken, gif that be done be fenȝeid furie, or not Ib.

Gif they did it throw the heat of furie and madnes Bisset II. 83/10.

Næ furious man nor utherwyse impos mentis may mak testament … induring the tyme of his furie and imperfectioun Mackenzie Laws & C. i. xiii. § 2.

Fury also defends against treason, blasphemy, and heresie
